Furthermore, the removal of the acid significantly decreased the yield of 3aa, illustrating the importance of the acid and the presence of the second reaction pathway in the reaction system (Scheme 6f). Polysubstituted azauracils represent highly important nitrogen-containing heterocyclic compounds that are widely found in biologically active molecules. Current synthetic methods primarily rely on expensive transition metals or often toxic photocatalysts to achieve CH functionalization of azauracils, making it imperative to develop simpler and more practical synthetic approaches. Electroorganic synthesis offers an excellent alternative strategy. Herein, we disclose an electrochemical CH silylation method for the synthesis of various silicon-substituted azauracils using azauracils and hydrosilanes as starting materials. This transformation is conducted in an undivided cell, offering operational simplicity, excellent substrate compatibility, and scalability to gram-scale synthesis. Furthermore, this strategy enables the late-stage derivatization of valuable molecules. Mechanistic studies reveal that azauracils capture silicon radicals through three distinct pathways, ultimately generating diverse polysubstituted azauracil derivatives. Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords Azauracils C–H functionalization Electroorganic synthesis Silylation Hydrosilanes 1 Introduction Azauracil derivatives represent a class of highly significant functional molecules, exhibiting unique biological activities such as antitumor, antibacterial, and antiviral properties [1]. Over the past few decades, organic chemists have focused on developing efficient methods for constructing multi-substituted azauracils [2], with direct CH functionalization being a promising strategy [3]. Traditional thermal reactions, including metal-catalyzed approaches, have enabled the synthesis of diverse azauracil derivatives (Scheme 1 a) [3b,4]. However, these methods often require transition metal catalysts, high temperature, or stoichiometric additives and are limited to forming CC and CP bonds. Recently, photocatalytic CH functionalization of azauracils has gained significant attention [5]. Through single-electron transfer, radical intermediates or further transformed cations and complex radicals can be captured by azauracils, enabling arylation [6], alkylation [7], acylation [8], and silylation [9] reactions (Scheme 1b). These advancements have greatly enriched the synthetic methods for multi-substituted azauracil derivatives, although challenges such as high usage of strong bases/oxidants or precious photocatalysts remain. Delightfully, the emergence of electroorganic synthesis has provided a novel approach for CH functionalization of azauracils [10]. However, this field is still in its infancy, with very few related studies reported. Electrochemical organic synthesis facilitates the transformation of organic molecules through electrochemical reactions, offering advantages such as high selectivity, environmental friendliness, and mild reaction conditions [11]. This method avoids the use of toxic reagents in traditional redox reactions, minimizes by-product formation, and allows precise control over reaction processes through potential regulation, making it suitable for complex molecule synthesis and green chemistry [12]. CH silylation is a crucial strategy for constructing silicon-containing organic molecules [13], and electroorganic synthesis provides an effective alternative to metal-catalyzed methods, representing a cutting-edge research direction [14]. Pioneering work by Wang, Rueping, He, and others has advanced this field significantly [15], yet electroorganic synthesis of multi-substituted silicon-containing azauracil derivatives remains unexplored. Building on our ongoing interest in nitrogen heterocycles [16], we have achieved electrochemical CH silylation of azauracils, eliminating the need for metal catalysts and oxidants (Scheme 1c). This transformation efficiently constructs complex polysubstituted silicon-containing azauracils, offering operational simplicity and mild reaction conditions that facilitate gram-scale preparation of target products. Additionally, the reaction exhibits excellent functional group tolerance, accommodating various azauracils and silanes within the reaction system, and enabling late-stage derivatization of biologically active molecules. 2 Results and discussion In our initial study, compound 2,4-dibenzyl-1,2,4-triazine-3,5(2H,4H)‑dione (1a) and triphenylsilane (2a) were selected as model substrates. The reaction was carried out in an undivided cell equipped with a graphite felt (GF) anode and a platinum plate cathode under an air atmosphere (Table 1 ). Initially, using NHPI (N-hydroxyphthalimide) as the hydrogen atom transfer (HAT) reagent with n Bu4NOAc as the electrolyte and trifluoroacetic acid (TFA) as the acid additive in acetone under constant current (5 mA) at room temperature for 5.5 h afforded the desired product 3aa in 85 % yield (entry 1). Substitution of acetone with CH3CN, DMSO, or DMF resulted in diminished yields (entries 2–4). The yield decreased significantly when alternative electrolytes were employed instead of n Bu4NOAc (entries 5–7). Several other possible HAT reagents, including TEMPO, triethylenediamine (DABCO) and quinuclidine were examined and no reaction occurred (entries 8 − 10). Also, the yield of product 3aa decreased when acetic acid is used, and without the addition of acid, the yield of 3aa is only 18 % (entries 11–12). Similarly, when the cathode material was replaced with carbon rod or platinum sheet, the yield decreased (entries 13–14). Finally, no reaction occurred in the absence of constant current. (entry 15). With the optimized reaction conditions in hand, we started to investigate the scope of azauracils (Scheme 2 ). Delightfully, azauracils containing both electron-rich (-CH3) and electron-deficient (-F, -Cl, -Br, -CF3, -CN) substituents on the N2 and N4 benzyl aromatic core gave the corresponding products (3ba-3ga) in moderate to high yields (39–80 %). It was found that N2/N4-methyl-containing azauracil was still able to produce product (3ha) in 77 % yield. Similarly, azauracils with different substituents including N2-isobutyl/N4-benzyl, N2-cyclohexyl/N4-ethyl, were well compatible, and the product 3ia and 3ja were obtained in 83 % and 57 % yields. Remarkably, this scheme was also applied to the N4-monosubstituted derivatives, yielding the corresponding products 3ka and 3la in 70–79 % yields.Finally, the substrate range was further extended in which azoxazole pyrimidines containing the same naphthalen-1-ylmethyl, cyclopropylmethyl, allyl, propargyl, or ethyl acetate groups in both positions underwent a successful transformation into the products (3ma-3qa) in 62- 80 % yields. Subsequently, the scope of hydrosilanes was investigated as well (Scheme 3 ). A series of homotrialkylsilanes with various substituents (including triethyl, triisopropyl, trihexyl, tris(trimethylsilyl), and tri-n‑butyl) demonstrated effective silylation under standard reaction conditions and gave the corresponding silylated products (3ab-3af) in 57–87 % yields. Moreover, trialkylsilanes of different sizes, such as tert‑butyldimethylsilane 2 g and diethylmethylsilane 2h, are also very compatible with each other, with yields of 83 % and 53 %. It is worth noting that phenyl- and benzyl-substituted silanes such as diphenylmethylsilane 2i, dimethylphenylsilane 2j, diphenyl‑tert‑butylsilane 2k, and dimethylbenzylsilane 2l are suitable substrates and the corresponding target products were easily obtained in yields of 26–70 %. Finally, in an attempt to expand the substrate scope, we tested 1,1,1,3,5,5,5-heptamethyltrisiloxane 2m as a substrate, the product was also successfully obtained with a yield of 25 %. Notably, we further explored the potential of this reaction for the development of azauracils. Firstly, we successfully introduced drug molecules and natural products such as Methyl benzoate, Ethyl benzoate, Clofibric acid, Diclazuril, 2,4-Dichlorophenoxyacetic acid, 2-Methoxycinnamic acid, Isoxepac and Aspirin into azauracils to react with triphenylsilane and synthesized the corresponding products in moderate to good yields (Scheme 4 ). To further enhance the product applicability, post-functionalization attempts were made; however, no significant progress was achieved (See experimental section in Supporting Information). Inspired by these results and to further assess the practicality of the reaction, gram-scale experiments were conducted, affording products 3aa, 3fa, 3ka, 3oa, and 3ag in 57–71 % yields (Scheme 5 ). To further investigate the reaction mechanism, we performed a series of controlled experiments (Scheme 6 ). Firstly, under standard reaction conditions, we detected hydrogen production for the reaction and therefore hypothesized that the hydrogen was produced by proton cathodic reduction, which provided an important clue to investigate the reaction mechanism (Scheme 6a). Secondly, the formation of the product 3aa was significantly inhibited by the addition of 4 equivalents of TEMPO under standard reaction conditions, suggesting that there may be a free radical pathway. Moreover, adducts of TEMPO with both the acetoxy radical (A) and azauracil radical (B), as well as the homocoupling product of azauracil (C), were detected by LCMS. (Scheme 6b). Subsequently, with the addition of 4 equivalents of BHT under standard reaction conditions, the isolated yield of 3aa was only 23 %, further proving the involvement of the free radical pathway, while the presence of trifluoroacetic acid radical (D) was detected by LCMS technique (Scheme 6c). Furthermore, the reaction was also inhibited by 1,1-diphenylethylene (Scheme 6d). LCMS analysis detected the triphenylsilyl radical (E), N-hydroxyphthalimide radical (F), protonated azauracil (Int-5), as well as the homocoupling product of silyl radical (H). The formation of the Cyclic voltammetry of related compounds in the acetone solvent and 0.05 M n Bu4NOAc as the electrolyte. Glass carbon, Pt wire, and Ag/AgCl were used as the working electrode, counter electrode, and reference electrode, at a scan rate of 0.1 Vs-1:(a) blank: electrolyte (0.05 M n Bu4NOAc), (b) red line: 1a (0.2 mmol), (c) green line: 2a (0.6 mmol), (d) blue line: 2a (0.6 mmol) + NHPI (0.1 mmol) To probe the mechanism of this electrochemical C(sp2)−H silylation reaction, several cyclic voltammetry (CV) experiments were conducted (Scheme 7 ). n Bu4NOAc showed a distinct oxidation peak (black line) at E½=0.93 V vs. Ag/AgCl, further confirming the presence of acetoxy radical. Azauracil 1a showed a distinct oxidation peak (red line) at E½=2.18 V vs. Ag/AgCl, indicating the presence of the third pathway in the reaction system. No significant oxidation potential (green line) was detected for triphenylsilane 2a, while the mixture system of 2a and NHPI detected a significant oxidation potential peak (blue line) at E½=1.56 V vs. Ag/AgCl. The above results indicate that n Bu4NOAc was oxidized first, followed by NHPI. We found that the mixed system of 1a+2a+NHPI has a significant oxidation potential at E½=2.46 V vs. Ag/AgCl, while for the mixed system of 1a+2a+NHPI+TFA, there is a significant oxidation potential only at E½=2.18 V vs. Ag/AgCl, which suggests that the addition of acid can reduce the difficulty of the reaction (Scheme SI, Figure S12). Based on above experiments and previous studies [9,10,17], we propose a plausible reaction mechanism as shown in Scheme 8 . Initially, anodic oxidation of the acetate anion (AcO⁻) generates the acetoxy radical (AcO•) through a single-electron transfer (SET) process at the anode surface. Subsequently, NHPI (N-hydroxyphthalimide) undergoes sequential deprotonation followed by anodic oxidation through a single-electron transfer (SET) process to generate the key phthalimide-N-oxyl radical intermediate lnt-1.The triphenylsilyl radical lnt-2 could be generated by hydrogen atom transfer (HAT) process between lnt-1 and 2a, a trace amount of lnt-2 undergoes self-coupling, and most of the lnt-2 and protonated azauracil lnt-5 add to generate lnt-6, which is a key intermediate in the reaction pathway. At the same time, the trifluoroacetate anion is oxidized at the anode to produce CF3COO•. Int-6 undergoes a HAT process predominantly mediated by Int-1, with supplementary assistance from the acetoxy radical (AcO•) and trifluoroacetate radical (CF₃COO•), leading to the formation of Int-7, which is subsequently deprotonated to produce the final product 3aa (path a). Another pathway is that the radical intermediate lnt-2 directly undergoes an addition reaction with azauracil 1a to produce the intermediate lnt-3, which in turn is oxidized at the anode and undergoes a single-electron transfer and deprotonation process to give 3aa. In addition, lnt-3 can undergo self-coupling, which can be detected by LCMS (path b). The last pathway is azauracil (1a) undergoes direct anodic oxidation via single-electron transfer (SET), generating the cationic radical intermediate lnt-8. This reactive species subsequently participates in radical cross-coupling with lnt-2, followed by deprotonation, to afford the final product 3aa. (path c). Meanwhile, the cathodic reduction of protons released hydrogen gas. 3 Conclusion In conclusion, we have developed an efficient and environmentally friendly electrochemical method for the CH silylation of azauracils using hydrosilanes. This approach leverages the advantages of electroorganic synthesis, including high selectivity, mild reaction conditions, and the avoidance of toxic reagents and transition metal catalysts. The method is operationally simple, scalable to gram-scale synthesis, and exhibits excellent substrate compatibility, enabling the late-stage derivatization of valuable molecules. Mechanistic studies reveal that azauracils capture silicon radicals through three distinct pathways, leading to the formation of complex polysubstituted azauracils. This work not only expands the synthetic toolbox for polysubstituted azauracils but also aligns with the principles of green chemistry by minimizing waste and reducing the reliance on precious catalysts. We believe this electrochemical strategy will inspire further advancements in the functionalization of heterocyclic compounds, particularly in the context of medicinal chemistry and materials science. coredata.dc:description: Polysubstituted azauracils represent highly important nitrogen-containing heterocyclic compounds that are widely found in biologically active molecules. Current synthetic methods primarily rely on expensive transition metals or often toxic photocatalysts to achieve CH functionalization of azauracils, making it imperative to develop simpler and more practical synthetic approaches. Electroorganic synthesis offers an excellent alternative strategy. Herein, we disclose an electrochemical CH silylation method for the synthesis of various silicon-substituted azauracils using azauracils and hydrosilanes as starting materials. This transformation is conducted in an undivided cell, offering operational simplicity, excellent substrate compatibility, and scalability to gram-scale synthesis. Furthermore, this strategy enables the late-stage derivatization of valuable molecules. Mechanistic studies reveal that azauracils capture silicon radicals through three distinct pathways, ultimately generating diverse polysubstituted azauracil derivatives.
